pr_title: Issue #833 - prototype migration and add automated migration test

timeline.message:
Add support for arbitrary database migration logic

This proof-of-concept extends our fhir-database-utils project with the
ability to define pre and post-migration steps for cases where an
idempotent "apply" just isn't enough.

It also illustrates the usage in two places:
1. drop the DATE_VALUE column and reorg all X_DATE_VALUES tables
2. drop the ENFORCED FK constraints in all X_COMPOSITES tables

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText:
I think you need to run this... https://dba.stackexchange.com/a/30233/202822
I think this should be a second set of parameters.
timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText: that answer is from 2012, i wonder if its still the "best practice".  it even mentions that the first runstats is more for older version...
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText:
RUNSTATS
REORG
RUNSTATS
REBIND packages
FLUSH PACKAGE CACHE DYNAMIC

i wonder how long all that takes?
at least with db2 on cloud, it should be running runstats automatically, although maybe its still "best practice" to run it before and after the reorg...will add it for now
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: on the dataset we had it took 10s of minutes in total
replies.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
I added the requested logic in Db2Adapter.runStatement...but I only did the RUNSTATS sandwhich and not the rebind/flush for now.
Then, later I decided that maybe the whole REORG statement is db2-specific, so I renamed the class to Db2ReorgTable (so I guess I could have had the logic here all-along...).
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.bodyText: might as well push this into the interface as a default implementation.
timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
didn't end up doing this one but can if you think its important.
instead, i opted to add "ThrowUnsupportedOperationException" in cases where we're trying to update objects that we shouldn't (i.e. tablespace and sequence).
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.bodyText: don't do anything here. we shouldn't make a new tablespace, or alter here.
timeline.author: prb112

replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.bodyText:
I've been reading through the steps included.  I think we should add Migration to the VERSION_HISTORY tracking table and DatabaseObjectType.
Without these steps, it'd be impossible to resume the specific migration in a deterministic way.  For instance, alter table would not work again, and fail.
timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
The updates should happen together in a transaction and should either fail or succeed together.
The migration steps themselves should have the logic of what versions they apply to and what versions they don't.
With that said, I'm not fundamentally opposed to adding Migrations to the VERSION_HISTORY if you think its important.
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText:
I think this is something we probably want to monitor if we transform data from one column to another.  I also think our re-indexing should resolve my concern (more of an intuition)
I think for what we have right now.  This is sufficient.
replies.author: prb112

timeline.bodyText: I like this approach 1..* instead of one at a time.
timeline.author: prb112

timeline.bodyText:
I'm leaning towards NOT dropping columns...
1 - we always leave a rollback point with the original data, and we can MOVE the data at any point, or re-index.
2 - it should be relatively transparent.
Thoughts?
timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
I'm torn on it.  I'd prefer not to create it going forward since its never used.  But I don't like the idea of some deployments having it and others not.  Hence the idea to drop it.  I think we could add a step to copy the data from that column into the LOW and HIGH columns if it makes us feel better.
However, I'd prefer to just tell the 2 people that installed version 4.0.0 that they need to be aware of it and just be done.
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText:
We discussed as a team and decided to NOT drop the old column.
We do drop the indices that were using the column though.
Also, we will not be adding the column going forward, so users on version 4.0.1 that upgrade to 4.1.0 or higher will have this extra column sitting around.
Also, we do NOT copy this older column's data into the DATE_START or DATE_END columns, so any old resources that had date values indexed should get updated to use the new approach.
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.author: prb112

timeline.bodyText: I'd say add a NO OP default here.  It'll be fairly repeatable for StoredProcedures or other NO OP content such as Tablespaces.

timeline.bodyText:
I think documenting the method.
Starting from the prior version, the Migration implements as a set of steps that are sequentially executed.
Also the set of IDatabaseStatements, maybe they should indicate if each step is idempotent.
Also a minor comment, to be consistent in this code base, shouldn't it be IMigration.
timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
added this javadoc:
    /**
     * Migrate from some previous version to the current version of this database object
     *
     * @param priorVersion
     *            the version being migrated from
     * @return a list of statements to be executed sequentially to bring a database object from the prior version to the
     *         current version
     * @implSpec this method should only be executed when the current version > priorVersion and so the steps need not be
     *         idempotent
     */


Also a minor comment, to be consistent in this code base, shouldn't it be IMigration.

I'm pretending I didn't see this part ;-). @JohnTimm

timeline.author: prb112

replies.bodyText:
We use the real VersionHistoryService for anywhere that needs a true version (like in the new DerbyMigrationTest).
Perhaps we could return a -1 (or a 0) here to avoid having the null checks on the apply methods, but I went with null since we were already using Integer arguments (and not ints).
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.bodyText:
if you apply this (say 2 steps)
step 1 alter table add column succeeds
step 2 move content (say these are in pre-steps)
what happens to the above.
is it idempotent? is it in a deterministic state?  right now I don't think we could successfully migrate beyond one step one version in a deterministic way.
I think we have to track the migration steps in VERSION_HISTORY and filter the successful steps.
timeline.author: prb112

timeline.message:
issue #833 - prototype migration and add automated migration test

1. added support for derby in `com.ibm.fhir.schema.app.Main`
    * dropped Db2 from the ResourceTypes-related class names since they
      are not really specific to Db2

2. added support for generating only a subset of the resource types from
FhirSchemaGenerator

3. refactored DerbyMaster to re-use a single connection (instead of
creating a new one for each apply) and added a constructor for passing a
VersionHistoryService instead of just always using the fake one
(AllVersionHistoryService)

4. added DerbyMigrationTest for testing migrations
    * uses dblook to infer the ddl from the db, then sorts the rows and
      compares them
    * copied the 4.0.1 FhirSchemaGenerator, FhirResourceTableGroup into
      the test folder (and prefixed with "Old" to disambiguate).  In the
      future we can use the cli jars to create the historic version of
      the schema instead

5. added placeholder script for downloading and deploying previous
versions of the fhir-persistence-schema cli jar to test migrations
    * once thats working, we should remove the "Old*" classes I added to
      fhir-persistence-schema/src/test/com/ibm/fhir/schema/derby and use
      the all-in-one cli jars to create them instead


Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - prototype migration and add automated migration test

1. added support for derby in `com.ibm.fhir.schema.app.Main`
    * dropped Db2 from the ResourceTypes-related class names since they
      are not really specific to Db2

2. added support for generating only a subset of the resource types from
FhirSchemaGenerator

3. refactored DerbyMaster to re-use a single connection (instead of
creating a new one for each apply) and added a constructor for passing a
VersionHistoryService instead of just always using the fake one
(AllVersionHistoryService)

4. added DerbyMigrationTest for testing migrations
    * uses dblook to infer the ddl from the db, then sorts the rows and
      compares them
    * copied the 4.0.1 FhirSchemaGenerator, FhirResourceTableGroup into
      the test folder (and prefixed with "Old" to disambiguate).  In the
      future we can use the cli jars to create the historic version of
      the schema instead

5. added placeholder script for downloading and deploying previous
versions of the fhir-persistence-schema cli jar to test migrations
    * once thats working, we should remove the "Old*" classes I added to
      fhir-persistence-schema/src/test/com/ibm/fhir/schema/derby and use
      the all-in-one cli jars to create them instead


Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

replies.bodyText: Ah, I expect not.  Main doesn't even try it because it skips allocateTenant when dbType == DERBY.
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText:
How should we handle for now?  Maybe we just add an @implNote to say it only works for multi-tenant schemas?
Or should we overload the constructor and let the class's user tell us if its for a multi-tenant schema or not?
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: @impl note works for me
replies.author: prb112

replies.bodyText: I added the @implNote to the class's javadoc...maybe i should have done it on the method too, but lets call it good for now
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.message:
issue #833 - updates per team review

1. added implNote to Old* classes in fhir-persistence-schema test dir

2. moved from `--derby` argument to a `--db-type` argument with values
from the new DbType enum (currently just "derby" or "db2")

3. cleaned up logic in `Table.apply(priorVersion, target)`

4. one last copyright update

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - updates per team review

1. added implNote to Old* classes in fhir-persistence-schema test dir

2. moved from `--derby` argument to a `--db-type` argument with values
from the new DbType enum (currently just "derby" or "db2")

3. cleaned up logic in `Table.apply(priorVersion, target)`

4. added a sample derby.properties file for use with the
fhir-persistence-schema Main method

5. one last copyright update

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

Add support for arbitrary database migration logic

This proof-of-concept extends our fhir-database-utils project with the
ability to define pre and post-migration steps for cases where an
idempotent "apply" just isn't enough.

It also illustrates the usage in two places:
1. drop the DATE_VALUE column and reorg all X_DATE_VALUES tables
2. drop the ENFORCED FK constraints in all X_COMPOSITES tables

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

Moved table reorg into db2Adapter and sandwhiched it with runstats

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - prototype migration and add automated migration test

1. added support for derby in `com.ibm.fhir.schema.app.Main`
    * dropped Db2 from the ResourceTypes-related class names since they
      are not really specific to Db2

2. added support for generating only a subset of the resource types from
FhirSchemaGenerator

3. refactored DerbyMaster to re-use a single connection (instead of
creating a new one for each apply) and added a constructor for passing a
VersionHistoryService instead of just always using the fake one
(AllVersionHistoryService)

4. added DerbyMigrationTest for testing migrations
    * uses dblook to infer the ddl from the db, then sorts the rows and
      compares them
    * copied the 4.0.1 FhirSchemaGenerator, FhirResourceTableGroup into
      the test folder (and prefixed with "Old" to disambiguate).  In the
      future we can use the cli jars to create the historic version of
      the schema instead

5. added placeholder script for downloading and deploying previous
versions of the fhir-persistence-schema cli jar to test migrations
    * once thats working, we should remove the "Old*" classes I added to
      fhir-persistence-schema/src/test/com/ibm/fhir/schema/derby and use
      the all-in-one cli jars to create them instead


Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - updates per team review

1. added implNote to Old* classes in fhir-persistence-schema test dir

2. moved from `--derby` argument to a `--db-type` argument with values
from the new DbType enum (currently just "derby" or "db2")

3. cleaned up logic in `Table.apply(priorVersion, target)`

4. added a sample derby.properties file for use with the
fhir-persistence-schema Main method

5. added javadoc to Migration.migrateFrom

6. renamed `IDatabaseAdapter.createProcedure` to
`createOrReplaceProcedure` to make it more clear that we don't need
normally need migration steps for procedures

7. added warning to `ProcedureDef.apply(priorVersion, target)` when one
or more migrations exist...we havn't worked out what the exact behavior
should be for Procedures yet

8. one last copyright update

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - updates per team review

1. added implNote to Old* classes in fhir-persistence-schema test dir

2. moved from `--derby` argument to a `--db-type` argument with values
from the new DbType enum (currently just "derby" or "db2")

4. added a sample derby.properties file for use with the
fhir-persistence-schema Main method

5. added javadoc to Migration.migrateFrom

6. renamed `IDatabaseAdapter.createProcedure` to
`createOrReplaceProcedure` to make it more clear that we don't need
normally need migration steps for procedures

7. added warning to `ProcedureDef.apply(priorVersion, target)` when one
or more migrations exist...we havn't worked out what the exact behavior
should be for Procedures yet

8. renamed Db2ReorgTable back to Db2Reorg

9. throw UnsupportedOperationException if apply(priorVersion, target) is
called for RowArrayTypes that need a migration

10. one last copyright update

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - add the DROP Column back in

removing the DROP of the DATE_VALUES column made the migrated 4.0.1
schema different from the 4.1.0 schema, which causes the migration test
to fail, so this commit adds the DROP back in

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - add the DROP Column back in

removing the DROP of the DATE_VALUES column made the migrated 4.0.1
schema different from the 4.1.0 schema, which causes the migration test
to fail, so this commit adds the DROP back in

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>

issue #833 - add migration logic for #706 and more

Previously, I forgot we made this schema change early in the 4.1.0 cycle
and so the migration test was starting with a schema that didn't exactly
match 4.0.1.

To make migration match the schema exactly (same columns in the same
order), I had to move these two "new" number columns from the middle of
the table definition to the end.

Additionally, I found that FhirSchemaGenerator was still including the
retired `DATE_VALUES` column in the global/resource-level DATES table.
While that table isn't used, I updated it to match the resource-specific
ones.

Also added an `@implNote` to PopulateResourceTypes per review comment.

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>
